problem: Question: A Eurodollar futures quote for the period between 5.1 and 5.35 years in the future is 97.1. The standard deviation of the change in the short-term interest rate in one year is 1.4%.What is the forward interest rate in an FRA? (Unit: decimal)
answer: The convexity-adjusted FRA forward rate is 0.02632907 (in decimal form).
reasoning: From the Eurodollar futures quote 97.1, the unadjusted futures rate is F = (100 − 97.1)/100 = 0.029. Using the convexity adjustment formula f = F − 0.5·σ²·T1·T2 with σ = 0.014, T1 = 5.1, and T2 = 5.35, we computed σ²·T1·T2 = 0.00534186 and thus the convexity adjustment CA = 0.5·0.00534186 = 0.00267093. Subtracting this from F gives the FRA forward rate f = 0.029 − 0.00267093 = 0.02632907.

state.problem: Question: A Eurodollar futures quote for the period between 5.1 and 5.35 years in the future is 97.1. The standard deviation of the change in the short-term interest rate in one year is 1.4%.What is the forward interest rate in an FRA? (Unit: decimal)
state.goal: Compute the forward interest rate in decimal form for the FRA corresponding to the 5.1–5.35 year period, using the given Eurodollar futures quote and interest rate volatility, and express the final answer as a single decimal number (e.g., 0.0315).
givens: Eurodollar futures quote for period between 5.1 and 5.35 years in the future: 97.1
Implied futures interest rate (unadjusted) = 100 − futures quote
Standard deviation of the change in the short-term interest rate in one year: 1.4% (= 0.014 in decimal)
Time to start of FRA from now: 5.1 years
Length of FRA period (approximate underlying rate maturity): 0.25 years (3 months), implied by 5.1 to 5.35 years
We are using the standard convexity adjustment approach for Eurodollar futures to infer the forward rate from the futures rate
unknowns: The unadjusted futures interest rate in decimal form
The convexity adjustment term to convert futures rate to forward rate
The convexity-adjusted forward interest rate for the FRA in decimal form
Any minor adjustments due to exact time conventions (e.g., year fractions) if required
invariants: All interest rates in intermediate and final answers must be in decimal form, not percentages (e.g., 0.031 instead of 3.1%).
Use year units consistently for time variables (e.g., 5.1 years, 0.25 years).
Eurodollar futures quote is converted to a futures rate as: futures_rate = (100 − quote) / 100 in decimal.
Convexity adjustment formula for Eurodollar futures must be applied consistently; any chosen standard formula must be applied using the same variance and time units throughout.
No mental math is allowed for any numerical step: all arithmetic, algebra, and exponentials must be done via Python.
Final output must be a single scalar forward rate in decimal form, clearly labeled as the FRA forward rate.

plan.title: Extract and restate all givens with units and symbols
plan.description: Identify and denote all given numerical values and terms, and map them to symbols: futures quote (Q = 97.1), volatility of short rate (sigma = 0.014), start time of FRA (T1 = 5.1 years), maturity of underlying rate (T2 = 5.35 years, or tenor = 0.25 years). Make clear which times are used in the convexity adjustment formula.
plan.expected_output: A compact list of symbols with their numerical values and units, and a note of which times (T1, T2, or tenor) will enter the convexity adjustment formula.
plan.result: Define symbols and values: Q = 97.1 (Eurodollar futures quote, unit: price index); F (unadjusted annualized futures interest rate, in decimal) will be computed from Q via F = (100 − Q)/100. Sigma (σ) = 0.014 (standard deviation of the annual change in the short-term interest rate, per year, in decimal). T1 = 5.1 years (time from today to the start of the underlying 3‑month period). T2 = 5.35 years (time from today to the end of the underlying 3‑month period). τ = T2 − T1 = 0.25 years (tenor/length of the underlying rate). For the convexity adjustment formula, the primary time inputs will be T1 (start time from now) and T2 (end time from now), commonly appearing as T1 and T2 (or equivalently T1 and T1+τ) in terms such as σ²·T1·T2; τ is used only as the underlying period length, not in the convexity term itself.

plan.title: Check required output format and unit consistency
plan.description: Confirm that the target output is the FRA forward rate expressed as a decimal (e.g., 0.0315), not as a percentage or a quote. Verify that all time variables are in years and that the volatility is in per-year terms (standard deviation of annual short rate change).
plan.expected_output: A short statement confirming that the forward rate must be in decimal form, that time is in years, and that volatility is treated as annual; also restate any needed conversions (e.g., percentage to decimal).
plan.result: The required output is the FRA forward rate expressed as a decimal (e.g., 0.0315, meaning 3.15%), not as a percentage or a price quote. All time variables (T1 = 5.1, T2 = 5.35, tenor τ = 0.25) are to be treated in units of years. The short‑rate volatility σ = 1.4% must be used in decimal, σ = 0.014, representing the annual standard deviation of the change in the short‑term interest rate. Any quoted percentages in the problem must be converted to decimal form before use in formulas.

plan.title: Convert the Eurodollar futures quote to an unadjusted futures interest rate
plan.description: Use the standard Eurodollar convention: futures rate (in %) = 100 − quote. Then convert this percentage to a decimal. MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.
plan.expected_output: The unadjusted annualized futures rate F in decimal form (e.g., 0.029 for 2.9%).
plan.result: The unadjusted annualized futures interest rate is F = 0.029 (in decimal form).

MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.. Extract all numbers and formulas, then compute using Python. No mental math. No approximations.
plan.expected_output: The unadjusted annualized futures rate F in decimal form (e.g., 0.029 for 2.9%).
plan.result: The unadjusted annualized futures interest rate is F = 0.029 in decimal form.

plan.title: Define the convexity adjustment formula to use
plan.description: State explicitly the chosen convexity adjustment formula that links the futures rate F to the forward rate f, in terms of the volatility sigma and the relevant times (such as f = F − 0.5 * sigma^2 * T1 * T2). Clarify how T1 and T2 (or tenor) are used in this formula, consistent with common Eurodollar convexity adjustment practice.
plan.expected_output: A clearly written mathematical formula expressing the forward rate f in terms of F, sigma, and the relevant time parameters, with each symbol defined.
plan.result:
Use the standard Eurodollar futures convexity‐adjustment relationship:
\nForward rate:  f = F − 0.5 · σ² · T1 · T2
\nwhere:
- F is the unadjusted annualized Eurodollar futures rate in decimal form, obtained from the futures quote (e.g., F = (100 − Q)/100),
- f is the corresponding forward rate in decimal form for the same underlying period (the FRA rate we seek),
- σ is the annual volatility (standard deviation) of the change in the short‑term interest rate, expressed in decimal (here σ = 0.014),
- T1 is the time in years from today to the start of the underlying 3‑month period (here T1 = 5.1),
- T2 is the time in years from today to the end of the underlying 3‑month period (here T2 = 5.35).
\nIn this formula, the convexity adjustment term 0.5·σ²·T1·T2 is subtracted from the futures rate F to obtain the forward rate f, capturing the effect of interest‑rate volatility over the interval between today and the underlying rate’s start and end dates.

plan.title: Compute the time parameters needed for the convexity adjustment

Even if these are already given, restate any differences (like T2 − T1). MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.

plan.result: Time parameters (in years): T1 = 5.1, T2 = 5.35, tau = 0.25 (where tau = T2 − T1).

step.title: Define the convexity adjustment formula to use
step.description: State explicitly the chosen convexity adjustment formula that links the futures rate F to the forward rate f, in terms of the volatility sigma and the relevant times (such as f = F − 0.5 * sigma^2 * T1 * T2). Clarify how T1 and T2 (or tenor) are used in this formula, consistent with common Eurodollar convexity adjustment practice.
step.expected_output: A clearly written mathematical formula expressing the forward rate f in terms of F, sigma, and the relevant time parameters, with each symbol defined.
step.result:
Use the standard Eurodollar futures convexity‐adjustment relationship:
\nForward rate:  f = F − 0.5 · σ² · T1 · T2
\nwhere:
- F is the unadjusted annualized Eurodollar futures rate in decimal form, obtained from the futures quote (e.g., F = (100 − Q)/100),
- f is the corresponding forward rate in decimal form for the same underlying period (the FRA rate we seek),
- σ is the annual volatility (standard deviation) of the change in the short‑term interest rate, expressed in decimal (here σ = 0.014),
- T1 is the time in years from today to the start of the underlying 3‑month period (here T1 = 5.1),
- T2 is the time in years from today to the end of the underlying 3‑month period (here T2 = 5.35).
\nIn this formula, the convexity adjustment term 0.5·σ²·T1·T2 is subtracted from the futures rate F to obtain the forward rate f, capturing the effect of interest‑rate volatility over the interval between today and the underlying rate’s start and end dates.

candidates.result:
We use the standard Eurodollar futures convexity adjustment formula:
\nForward rate:  f = F − 0.5 · σ² · T1 · T2
\nwhere:
- f is the convexity-adjusted forward interest rate (in decimal) for the underlying 3‑month period from T1 to T2,
- F is the unadjusted annualized Eurodollar futures interest rate implied by the futures quote (in decimal),
- σ is the annual volatility of the short-term interest rate (in decimal),
- T1 is the time in years from today to the start of the underlying 3‑month period (here T1 = 5.1),
- T2 is the time in years from today to the end of the underlying 3‑month period (here T2 = 5.35).
\nThe product σ² · T1 · T2 captures the variance of the underlying rate over the relevant horizon, and the factor 0.5 reflects the second-order (convexity) effect that makes the futures rate F slightly higher than the corresponding forward rate f when rates are positively correlated with discount factors.
candidates.evidence: The described formula f = F − 0.5·σ²·T1·T2 is the commonly used convexity adjustment for Eurodollar futures in many textbooks: the futures rate exceeds the forward rate by approximately 0.5·σ²·T1·T2. T1 and T2 are the start and end times of the underlying rate period, both in years, consistent with the problem’s givens.
assumptions_used: Use the standard textbook approximation that the difference between the Eurodollar futures rate and the corresponding forward rate is 0.5·σ²·T1·T2, with σ being the annualized short-rate volatility.

Assume that the interest rate dynamics and correlation structure satisfy the usual conditions under which this convexity adjustment formula is valid (small volatility, approximately lognormal/normal behavior of rates, and standard no-arbitrage relationships).
Assume that T1 and T2, not the tenor alone, enter the adjustment term, which matches the formulation requested in the plan (σ²·T1·T2).

candidates.result:
Use the standard Eurodollar futures convexity adjustment: let F be the annualized Eurodollar futures rate in decimal for the 3‑month period from T1 to T2, with T1 (in years) the time from today to the start of the underlying 3‑month period and T2 (in years) the time from today to its end, and let σ be the annual volatility of the short rate (in decimal). The forward rate f for the corresponding FRA is then
\nf = F − 0.5 · σ² · T1 · T2
\nwhere:
- F is the quoted futures rate in decimal.
- f is the convexity‑adjusted forward (FRA) rate in decimal.
- σ is the standard deviation of the annual change in the short‑term rate.
- T1 is the start time of the underlying accrual period (in years from today).
- T2 is the end time of the underlying accrual period (in years from today).\nThis formula uses the product T1·T2 as the time factor in the convexity adjustment.
candidates.evidence: The usual convexity adjustment between a Eurodollar futures rate and the corresponding forward Libor rate under a simple short‑rate model (e.g., Ho–Lee–type) is linear in the variance term and given by f = F − 0.5 σ² T1 T2. T1 and T2 enter as the start and end times of the underlying 3‑month rate, while σ is the annual short‑rate volatility; the adjustment is subtracted from the futures rate to obtain the forward rate.
assumptions_used: Assumed the standard textbook Eurodollar futures convexity adjustment formula f = F − 0.5 σ² T1 T2 as used in many derivatives references (e.g., Hull).

Assumed the underlying 3‑month tenor itself does not separately enter the convexity formula beyond being reflected in T2 = T1 + tenor.
